body: Maven "hangs" because of the absurdly large directory that it tries to package into the jar. It does in fact eventually finish, given enough time.
@niketanpansare @nakul02 thanks for catching this. LGTM from my side.
Applied similar changes to python performance test scripts.

It turns out that we don't need to specify the `spark.akka.frameSize=128` or `spark.rpc.message.maxSize=128`. According to the documentation for [Spark 1.6 ](https://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.1/configuration.html), that is already the default size. Also, in the current spark master, the [value defaults](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/util/RpcUtils.scala#L59) to 128.
I also discussed this in an offline conversation with @niketanpansare.

I think we should remove this parameters from all our scripts.

For the python scripts, we'll need to pass the newly introduced `--deploy-mode` parameter to other parts of the script. 
Ping @krishnakalyan3.

@j143 I just checked out the branch to debug it a little bit, but there are still a number of compilation issues. Overall, I think you make your life too hard by trying to cover part 2 and part 3 all in one step. I would recommend to focus only on part 2 for now, start with one or two basic tests, and modify the language layer and hop/lop compilation accordingly. Also, you might want to set the `FunctionOp._singleOutFun` only if required, i.e., when a function is actually used inside an expression. This would guarantee that you don't affect any other functions or existing scripts, you can focus on your new tests, and there is almost no risk pushing this PR via separate parts into master.
@nakul02 addressed your comments.
LGTM

@niketanpansare In general, it makes sense to be able to use the previous layer's output shape for the next layer's input shape (and the functions in `nn` do that), so it should be fine to do it here as well.  The bigger issue for me though is that I don't think hacks like this should be necessary.  The shapes *can* (assuming the engine worked well....) all be computed at compile time, and thus the shape variables that are returned from every function in `nn` *should* be able to be reliably used, without any unknown values.  The fact that there are still unknown values to me just signifies that the engine needs to be improved in the general case.
@dusenberrymw Yes, I agree. Constant propagation part of our engine needs more work.
Btw, should we consider moving these shapes from forward to init?

well, without looking into the details - this change seems to hide two size propagation issues of the ConvolutionOp. First, during (basic) dynamic recompilation we have an unconditional compilation scope of a single DAG, so unless there are data-dependent operators such as table, rand(sum(X),1), etc all dimension sizes become known. I would recommend to look at operators like DataGenOp and adapt the same approach. Also note that IPA for size propagation across functions simply reuses the dynamic recompilation infrastructure. So once the size propagation of the ConvolutionOp is fixed, it would implicitly remove the need for dynamic recompilation altogether. Second, I think the ConvolutionOp does also not correctly mark operators for dynamic recompilation. Normally, we mark operators for dynamic recompilation if the exec type is spark (potentially due to unknowns) and dimensions/sparsity is unknown or in forced cp exec type if the dimensiosn are unknown. Neither applies here, because the ConvolutionOp does not support spark operations.

@mboehm7 There are 2 issues here:
1. ConvolutionOp is not marked for recompilation as they are on CP.
2. Evaluation of the below expression should have happened at compile-time via constant propagation:

```
Hout = as.integer(floor((Hin + 2*padh - Hf)/strideh + 1))
Wout = as.integer(floor((Win + 2*padw - Wf)/stridew + 1))
```

The scenario is as follows: the first convolution precisely knows the inputs and output dimensions `(N, K*Hout*Wout)` and propagates that. But since we donot have tensor support, we only know  `K*Hout*Wout` and not Hout and Wout.

yes, my point was that (1) can be easily fixed, and (2) even if the ConvolutionOp has DAGs of operations instead of literals as input parameters, these can be easily evaluated during dynamic recompilation (with an approach similar to the rows/cols parameters of the DatagenOp) - so there is no need to infer them from the parent, which can create problems due to the order to size propagation. Also, I would recommend to remove `_cachedParams` as it can lead to incorrect sizes and thus incorrect results if a function is called with different parameters and dynamic recompilation needs to actually update the parameters.

Sure, I can remove _cachedParams. But the core problem still exists: 'unnecessary computation of constant shapes in for loop'. There are two possible solutions:
1. Refactor nn script to move shape computation to init. Please see 1965 jira.
2. Constant propagation and removing these computation outside the for loop. That is no need for recomputing the DAG of operations during  every iteration via dynamic recompilation.

Without either of these solutions, we are unnecessarily increasing the SystemML overhead. It is possible to easily construct a neural network case where gpu based forward propagation is so fast that recompilation time is overhead.

For correctness, I ran `Z = X %*% Y` where `X: i X j` with sparsity `sp1` and `Y: j X k` with sparsity `sp2`:
- CP (apache master)
- With `-gpu` (this PR)
- With `-gpu` (apache master)

I compared the last two results with CP with epsilon (`0.1, 0.0001, 0.0000001, 0.0000000001 and 0.0000000000001`) and populated the last two columns for:
```
for i in 5000 1000 1
do
for j in 5000 1000 1
do
for k in 5000 1000 1
do
for sp1 in 0.9 0.2 0.1 0.01
do
for sp2 in 0.9 0.2 0.1 0.01
do
        ...
done
...
```

The above setup covers every combination of sparse-dense, matrix-vector, matrix-matrix combinations.

All the results match for every combination with every epsilon except following and that too for only `1.0E-13` epsilon:

```
leftNumRows,leftNumCols,rightNumCols,leftSparsity,rightSparsity
5000,5000,5000,0.9,0.1
5000,5000,1000,0.9,0.1
5000,1000,5000,0.9,0.2
5000,1000,1000,0.9,0.2
1000,5000,5000,0.9,0.1
1000,5000,1000,0.9,0.1
1000,1000,5000,0.9,0.2
1000,1000,1000,0.9,0.2
1,5000,5000,0.9,0.1
1,5000,1000,0.9,0.1
```

For lower epsilon (`0.0000000001`), all the above cases match.
@nakul02 can you please review this PR ?

Could you please encapsulate the correctness testing you did into the unit tests?

In master, if either of the matrices is sparse, the output matrix maybe sparse.
With this PR, if either of the matrices is dense, the output is always dense. There is a memory trade-off to consider, besides the performance.
Updated the title of the PR to make the goal of this PR explicit: minimize conversions. We can deal with tradeoffs in a different PR.

Thank you for the documentation additions!
Could you please also take care of the `swap` and `cusparseOp` like helper functions and add/edit unit tests?
Updated the junit tests. I would prefer to keep `swap` and `cusparseOp` methods as is.

Ok, other than the disagreeable swap and cusparseOp, everything LGTM. 
Overall LGTM. Please feel free to merge.
Thanks. I will merge :)
